artist: Kitagawa Utamaro; Published by Tsutaya Jūzaburō
marks: Nosera re te / miru yu)gao no / Hano_gi / hito no  Utamaro hitsu
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
text: Hanaōgi (literally, “flower fan”) may well be the most frequently depicted woman in ukiyo-e. In fact, Hanaōgi was a pseudonym used by several generations of courtesans from the Ōgiya house, one of the most exclusive brothels in the Yoshiwara. This print represents Hanaōgi IV, the highest-ranked courtesan in the Ōgiya from 1791 through 1797. The oblong cartouche contains a poem comparing the pale beauty of Hanaōgi by moonlight to a delicate moonflower. Blossoming moonflowers arranged on a flower-fan and Hanaōgi’s face after moonrise are so adorable that people never tire of seeing them and forget that autumn is coming.
title: Courtesan Hanaōgi of the Ōgiya House
